llm_processed_output.source_summary: This paper examines the Portuguese art of war in Northern Morocco during the 15th century. It discusses the motives behind Portuguese expansionism in Morocco, including political, economic, and social reasons. The paper highlights the shift in Portuguese military tactics from Iberian Reconquista methods to a model of restricted territorial occupation in Morocco, characterized by guerrilla warfare, sieges, and privateering actions. It also approaches changes in the defense systems of Portuguese strongholds in North Africa in response to Moroccan armies equipped with fire weaponry. The study points out that the Portuguese expansion project dates back to the late 13th century. The conquest of Ceuta in 1415 was a significant starting point, followed by Ksar es-Seghir in 1458, Asilah, and Tangier in 1471. The Portuguese adopted a restricted model of occupation due to structural deficiencies. The paper also examines the maritime war, defensive war, and guerrilla warfare tactics employed by the Portuguese. The Portuguese strongholds served as a deterrent to North African privateering activity and supported Portuguese navigation. The article also mentions the importance of the battle of Alcácer Quibir (Ksar el-Kebir) in 1578. The paper also specifically mentions that in Asilah the stronghold area was reduced to less than half of the previously occupied area, with the wall running parallel to the beach and that structures to provide garrisons with access to water (couraças) were built by 1502 in Asilah.
